pr_title: Move delete analysis to the analyzer

timeline.author: martint

timeline.bodyText: Why that happened? Does it deserve a comment in the code?
timeline.author: kokosing
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -783,6 +787,7 @@ public void addColumnMask(Table table, String column, Expression mask)
                     NodeRef<Table> table = entry.getKey();
 
                     List<ColumnInfo> columns = referencedFields.get(table).stream()
+                            .filter(field -> field.getName().isPresent())

replies.bodyText: When a table is analyzed during delete, the engine performs all access checks, including masks. The synthetic column that contains the row id used for deletion doesn’t have a name, which breaks the assumption this code had. I’ll add a comment.
replies.author: martint

replies.bodyText:
This is what I suspected. But it was easy because I saw change that introduced this.
Thanks
replies.author: kokosing

timeline.message:
Move delete analysis to the analyzer

The derivation of the row id field was being done during planning
instead of analysis. This also resulted in having to special-case
the planning of the source table plan.

timeline.bodyText: Should we add a check afterwards that the count matches unless it is a delete query?
timeline.author: dain
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -783,6 +787,7 @@ public void addColumnMask(Table table, String column, Expression mask)
                     NodeRef<Table> table = entry.getKey();
 
                     List<ColumnInfo> columns = referencedFields.get(table).stream()
+                            .filter(field -> field.getName().isPresent()) // For DELETE queries, the synthetic column for row id doesn't have a name

replies.bodyText: No, I don't think so. This piece of code doesn't particularly care about whether it's a DELETE. It should work generically for any case where fields without a name are synthesized. The comment is there to clarify why that might happen.
replies.author: martint
